abstract: Joseph Cedar, the writer and director of "Footnote," discusses elements of his film playing at the New York Film Festival.
snippet: Joseph Cedar, the writer and director of "Footnote," discusses elements of his film playing at the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: In his latest film "Footnote," the writer and director Joseph Cedar uses Hebrew philology and Talmudic scholarship to weave together a dramatic mystery. Concerning a father and son who are rival professors at a university, the movie looks at how a scholar can devote his life to a single topic of study. When he wrote about it at Telluride, A. O. Scott said the film "blends academic satire, classic Jewish humor and an almost Shakespearean sense of the tragic potential of the paternal bond." "Footnote" is screening at the New York Film Festival this week and in this video, Mr. Cedar discusses elements of the film and some of the research he did to put it together.
